Also, I can't easily find a place where the name of the recognized device is placed. This is easy to find in cheese, unsure why this basic info can't be displayed for the user

it could be a nice simple camera app.

description: Kamoso is a simple webcam application from KDE project that just works. Absolutely Wonderful and some Crazy Effects also. Tested on multiple Distributions like openSUSE, Arch, Debian, Fedora etc.
nothing works well

all mirror imaged on KDE Neon

No technical problems, runs smoothly.
There NEEDS to be a way to turn filters off again; The filters would benefit from being named; There are basically no configuration options.
Then again, I liked that "mirror image" was an option that stacks with filters and not a filter itself.
Basic webcam app that works great!!

Everything works fine, except the feature to switch to other camera devices. When I click on the box showing the currently selected camera, execting to be shown a list of camera devices, nothing happens.
summary: I cannot select the other camera

description: Don't allow to select webcams
Doesn't record audio. Please look into this, if possible. I am also checking it on my hardware too.
crash on open

The only drawback - which is kind of common, amongst some FOSS software, is the use of the open source codecs that ONLY save the video in MKV format.

I mean the development of these formats was a great idea in the time when people were rebelling against Microsoft monopilising everything with their own formats.... but now as Microsoft has lost the format wars, MKV - while it is a very good compression and video quality - it's kind of gone and got lost in the mists of time and history and is vanishing into obscurity.

I'd like to see this program revamped into running MP4 by using the H265 compressor - with very high compression ratios.

I'd also like to see it have a few settings like where to save the files etc... 

Other than that it's an excellent piece of software.
summary: It's good, it's simple and it works

description:
It's simple, light, fast and works perfectly for me. 

I use it as a mirror.
It works and i can use it so simple
summary: It works and i can use it so simple

description:
For Christ's sake people - come out of the "Open Sores" mentality and use H264 or H265.

MKV comes from the days when Microsoft was trying rule the universe with their own proprietary formats to "product lock in" everyone - and MKV was just one more noble out to this, and it has not been taken up - it's just faded away into oblivion... No one uses it.
summary: It's great software - but MKV is a dinosaur format

description: this one is like Cheese, but does not Freeze. Could be better like with less lag but simple enough for any basic user
This app records video in MKV format. MKV files are often 3x larger than MP4 and OpenH264 is open-source.

For some reason I get like 1-5fps on my logitech c920, where OBS-Studio gets a solid 60fps. It lacks basic configuration features. If you need a standalone webcam app, use cheese instead, this is trash.
This app worked with Dell Latitude 5000 series integrated camera. I did not tried to record videos, only took pictures.

This app could definitely be better, but I'm just happy that it records videos and they are actually relatively good quality!
